pros: I have been with this College for over 8 years and I have advanced in my position 5 times. Each career advance has brought new challenges and opportunities to expand my skill sets and to learn and grow in the education field. The support for career advancement is tremendous if you are willing to step up . The culture at Carrington is one of creative expression and "care" for colleagues. I  work with extraordinarily committed colleagues who delight in the success of our students and the successes of other colleagues. We celebrate our students and each other at every group event. I feel like I contribute to the greater good of the communities we serve at each and every campus location. The President of the College is committed to student success and support and that makes everything about our students, as it should be at any higher education institution.
cons: There are always special circumstances where we cannot affect change for some students, and that can feel discouraging. Some days are long, but it is well worth it.

pros: Students are the only pro anymore.
cons: Management was wiped out.  Since then, they have "regional" or home office folks taking over... or trying to in very poor fashion.  No one knows how to do anything, yet they had six months to figure it out before they laid everyone off.  Last Friday, the Regional Enrollment Services manager sent out an email in error to the entire Sacramento Campus... listing which employees were on the hit list basically (people that in his opinion were "negative, or culturally not a good fit").  the people on his list happened to be very respected employees on the campus, and were the same employees that voiced their concerns at a Town Hall.  Coincidence? Everyone was shocked that he hadn't been fired today.  The morale that he was worried about in his email is now damaged beyond repair.  No one trusts the management.  It's no longer a fun place to work, or a place to be proud of.

pros: In my experience this organization is consistently looking to provide its students and staff with the most up to date resources. methods, and technology available.  I've enjoyed getting to do in my profession every day what current literature says companies "are going to start doing".  The organization has grown increadibly over the last few years and has become more thoughtful, measured, and deliberate in its actions.  Great place to work!
cons: The student needs always come first, so if you are looking to work at an organization that you can just punch a clock or process widgets, this isn't it.  Our students work  hard every day just to be here, the expectation is well set at the highest levels that colleagues are expected to meet students where they are and work just as hard to help them succeed. You won't do well, if you don't have that focus every day.

pros: The only pro I can think of is that my coworkers are fabulous. We have all been committed to the success of the student, and we work hard and well together to make that happen. Unfortunately, management changes have nullified most of that. Formerly happy and dedicated team members (including me) are fleeing in droves.
cons:
1. Incompetent upper management. They've been rolling out new procedures since January, only they are never ready on time. Meanwhile, they forbid us to use the old ones. And they make their changes for how we are to do things with zero input from the people on the ground who actually know what might or might not work or what pitfalls to avoid. It's a dysfunctional mess.
2. They are abusing the full-time faculty that are left by refusing to replace the ones who have fled. They require those who are left to fill in--won't allow substitutes to be used or hired. Guess who's leaving now??? 
3. They sell their overpriced programs to students with the promise that they will receive an extra level of support to succeed. That used to be true, but now with the staffing shortages, that isn't possible. The students are getting less than they are paying for.
I could go on, but you get the picture. Run away! Don't work here. I'm taking my own advice and have a new job starting in 8 weeks.

pros: For a while, you could convince yourself that you were truly making a difference in the lives of people who needed a hand up. That is no longer the case due to managerial decisions.
cons: If you want to dedicate every waking moment to stroking the fragile, yet gigantic ego of upper management like your job depends on it (because it will), this is the place for you. If you enjoy backbiting and gossiping and mean-spirited daily interactions with those who make decisions about your career and your future, this place is for you. If you thrive in an environment where your skills, talents, level of commitment to the company and your students and your drive to help others doesn't matter if you're not willing to stroke the gigantic ego of those who make up titles for themselves and insist that you call them by said phony titles, then this place is going to be a great fit. If you want to be a lap-dog or a corporate zombie who exists only to allow someone to climb up your back on their way to the top while you stay silent and just let it happen, this is the job for you.

pros: A few individuals are really trying to make it positive
cons: Directives come from all directions. There are literally multiple areas that make demands on staff..it's overwhelming....and no one at the upper levels has a handle on it. The thinking seems to be that if the directives are constantly piled on, there will  a miraculous improvement in services. Each campus issues directives, the home office issues directives, California issues directives, DeVry issues directives, each separate division and department within the company issues directives. I can work on these "directives" for days at a time without ever having contact with a student...my main job!

pros: Carrington College is a large company that is part of an even larger corporation called DeVry. Because they are such a large company this helps make our benefits that much better. One of these benefits the incredible low portion we have to pay for medical coverage and our dental is free. All full time employees get 2 weeks paid vacation the first year of employment. We have incredible resources available to us because of the DeVry name. Another benefit is the ability to advance your career while working here. We have free on line tuition towards a better degree while employed with DeVry. The fact that the company is international gives you the opportunity to go work in different parts of the world. Those are just a few of the perks. I love working for this company!
cons: There really are no negatives to working for Carrington College. But if I had to pick something it would be space. At the campus I work at we have outgrown our space and we are all sharing offices until our new campus can be built.

review_title: Disruptive campus visits from corporate office
pros: Our focus is on student success as it should be.  Great facilities and programs.
cons: The corporate home office leader visits are disruptive and unecessary.  Our enrollments are shrinking and many people are resigning.  The environment here is pretty unstable.

review_title: Contact Center - Nearly impossible to move out to any other branch of DeVry Inc.
job_title: Contact Center Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Simple duties, inbound and outbound scripts.
cons:
Quick to master and excel at inbound and outbound scripted calls; no room for growth; unprofessional co workers; favoritism. 

While middle management (supervisors) are attempting to create a positive, learning environment, the position simply does not challenge or promote any sort of professional growth that would satisfy an employee who has higher hopes than a call center representative. There are many instances of favoritism such as altered work schedules, team placement and leniency on unprofessional dress code that is astonishing for anyone who has any sort of employment background in an office setting.

review_title: Corporate mentality with little regard to employee happiness.
job_title: Surgical Technology Instructor in Citrus Heights, CA
pros: The people that work there are the only good thing about this company. The instructors are people that really want students to succeed in their chosen field of study, for the most part.
cons: They say they care about their employees, however there is little regard for the people that actually teach in the classrooms. The salaries are not competitive at all.  They claim the annual raises are based on performance, but ever single person on camps received the same percentage of increase. The medical benefits keep getting more and more expensive ever year. Lately, it seems as if all this company cares about is making money regardless of the student grades or if students are failing a course.

pros: I truly enjoy the role I play at Carrington. I’m given the opportunity to learn and apply my prior skills and knowledge to improve the overall service Carrington can offer. I have a great working relationship with my supervisor and colleagues. Leadership makes the effort to provide a transparent view on the college’s vision and objectives. I see nothing but opportunities to improve and make Carrington the best. I enjoy when the college shares student successes stories and we hear how we’ve help change a student’s life for the better. The staff at Carrington are passionate about what they do and I’m glad to be a part of that environment.
cons: The upside Carrington is growing, but the downside is with growth comes the need to change quickly. You have to be able to handle it and wear different hats.

job_title: Medical Assisting Instructor in Stockton, CA
pros:
My colleagues and coworkers- they were the best! 
The students have such a drive to better themselves- its inspiring. 
Fridays off! (For the most part)
cons:
Lack of communication with management and upper management- you as an instructor are 99.9% in the dark. 
Pay- you will not recieve appropriate compensation and value in comparison to the work and responsibility you will have and what will continue to be put on your plate. They lack the ability to say "Good Job!", let alone a review and raise. 
You are not supported as an instructor- your curriculum that you will be asked to teach is not complete and you can not veer from the structure set. The curriculum also repeats itself term to term and when you alert an PD they say- it'll get fixed for the next go around, but it doesn't. 
Positions that come available are filled very sketchy

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Long term colleagues are a close net group of people who welcome new (non-regional management) colleagues kindly. We are all friendly and fun. The students keep us going, especially those who return after graduating just to check in and visit.
cons:
The home office (corporate) decided to lay off our mangers. They fired people who have been with the company for decades with NO NOTICE. When the company teaches out a program, those instructors are given several months notice, but they decided not to follow the "Carrington cares" model when it comes to their loyalty to colleagues who have given their entire life to the company. 

The people who were given the new regional management positions were appointed, hand picked by corporate. There is now very little room for upward mobility, or none at all depending on your department. 

Great job on the "new model," guys, great job.

pros: Some of the people here are amazing people, I made some lifelong friends here.
cons: The company is struggling and has had lay offs 3 years in a row. Management is not receptive to colleagues’ concerns or solutions to existing issues. There is a drama culture at times. They also underpay their employees and expect 150% from everyone. They also run a skeleton crew, so there are never enough enrollment or finance advisors. They will combine roles to save money on colleagues salaries. Also, when Carrington was acquired by SJVC it was an extremely sloppy transition and benefits became worse.

pros: Carrington College has been an amazing place to work and grow both personally and professionally.  Anyone with a good work ethic and passion for helping people can grow within the organization.  Senior leadership consistently communicates with authenticity and is very transparent about the direction the college is heading.
cons: Although it has helped with identifying creative new ways to go about accomplishing tasks, completing projects, and following through on various items in a timely manner, resources can sometimes be limited.  Without effective time management and organization, people can feel overwhelmed by the number of items on their plate.

pros:
Carrington College engages me as an employee.  

I have worked for several college systems.  All of them are student centric and strive to deliver stellar education and provide solid outcomes for students.  Carrington is no different in that regard.  Where Carrington excels is taking that same culture and extends it to its colleagues.  There is genuine interest in seeing colleagues have rewarding work experiences.  I have been coached to recognize three positive behaviors, results, etc. for every piece of constructive criticism. 

Because of the culture, colleagues work hard, engage in synergistic ways, and are intrinsically rewarded by the collective accomplishments of the campus.  

 I really enjoy coming to work each day.
cons: I find none worthy of note.

pros:
We have above average medical, dental, 401K, vacation, profit sharing and tuition benefits.  This this is possible because we are part of the larger organization of DeVry Education Group.  

We have a direct voice and input in our college planning process.  This is due to Carrington's accreditation and more easily manageable with our smaller size. All colleagues have access to recommend changes and are institutionally granted a voice.  Because of class schedules, most colleagues have to work only 1/2 Saturday every other month.

Carrington invests in colleague training and fosters the environment for internal promotions.
cons: With all of the changes with the formerly separate colleges, there isn't as much current process documentation as there should be.

job_title: Student Finance Team Lead in Mesa, AZ
pros: Helping students achieve their goals was the best part of the job.  Pay and benefits were ok. The facilities were nice and the equipment and resources that were available to the students were above average for a school of this size.
cons: Management skill at campus and corporate levels is lacking.  Zero work/life balance for the non-management employees. Too much overtime and inflexible schedules. The performance review process was not representative of the work that was done.  Customer input was never included. It was a popularity contest determined by management. There are virtually no advancement opportunities only lateral ones.

pros: The Carrington College culture is what makes this college the best.  There is truly a air of caring for employees and students and bringing the best out of both.  The culture here creates a strong family, one that i'm proud to be a part of.
cons: Workload is pretty heavy, but we're a growing school and with that come multiple hats, fingers in many pies, and hectic days.  It does make the day fly by!

review_title: Poor oversite and lack of vision from complacent leadership
pros: Several of the departments are very pro work-from-home or remotely.
cons: The leadership team lacks any vision and it seems they have no real desire to do anything other then prep the company for a sale while trying to convince the employees everything is OK.

pros: Salary at the time I left!
cons: Same as now. Senior Management haf no clue how to run a skills based college.  It still is all about the numbers! Keep all students , cheaters, drug users on campus, students who cannot pass minimum competency exams, students who come late, leave early  basically leave your integrity at the door and pass everyone or your on your way out. I know so many people that were with Apollo/Carrington who were responsible for making Apollo the college Devry wanted. They bought it and killed it. Everyone who left is so much happier and healthier for doing so.  I would never recommend this college to students or perspective employee's!

review_title: Couldn't ask for a better group of people to work with
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Leandro, CA
pros: I really enjoy being a part of a company who strives to make educational and career goals come true for our students. Everyone that I work with at the San Leandro Campus is kind, fun, hard working, and caring. My coworkers are hands down the best group of people I have ever worked with.
cons: The expectation of the employees is that you are here to meet all student needs. Meaning that you are going to have to be flexible with your schedule. If you are someone who can't be flexible then this might not be the best place for you.

review_title: Great place for experience - terrible for advancement
pros:
The majority of the people at Carrington are extremely great people who are passionate about what they do.  In the years I've worked here, I've made some great friends and met wonderful people who have helped me mature professionally.  It is possible to take on stretch assignments and additional duties to further your experience in different areas that you may be interested in.  Many opportunities to strengthen your resume through these.

As hard as it is to get promoted it's equally hard to lose you as an employee, so if you'd like somewhere with pretty nice benefits that you can coast for some time this is not a bad gig.
cons:
You have the opportunity to take on additional duties - but don't expect this to turn into a promotion or to be compensated for the additional work you've taken on.  This is a great place to gain experience in a field of interest, but be prepared to leave the company to be compensated fairly for the work that you do.  Quite a few departments encourage employees to take on additional work with hints of a future promotion; however, this promotion or compensation rarely materialize.  There is also a lot of turnover without transition planning - once people leave, historical data, processes, or even basics of what their job entails are hard to find - making future decisions difficult and leaving current employees starting at square one picking up the pieces.  Employees are often transitioned to 'interim' directors, managers, etc without receiving any sort of compensation... and interim periods can be extremely long as it takes this companyquite long, on average, to find and hire a new employee (leading to increased workloads and stress).  The promise is that this additional work will be temporary, but once it is being taken care of - finding a replacement is no longer a priority and these duties typically become yours.  This is a problem that affects almost every department and campus - have heard the complaint of being overworked from many within the system.

Most discussions regarding workload, compensation, pay grade, etc are closed door with your manager, so if there is favoritism (which runs rampant within the company) your concerns are tied nearly exclusively to your manager and what they want to do or can accomplish for you.  Very political to work your way up the ladder rather than based on the job you perform.  There are many weak managers within the company that are mostly talk, saying they want to help you with your concerns, but never actually follow through.  Other managers have ridiculously high expectations while others have extremely low expectations, so your performance may be superior to a colleague's but your reviews will not reflect that.

Demoralizing that lesser performing team members (or even incompetent team members) are kept on or given promotions due to favoritism or team members taking this person's duties to get the job done. 

Great in the short term to gather experience and meet nice people, but don't expect to grow your career here.  The frustrations of being overworked, under-appreciated, dealing with incompetent teammates is likely something you'll experience after 6 months to a year.  If this is something you can handle long term, I applaud you.

job_title: Medical Billing and Coding Instructor in Boise, ID
pros: The schedule format - Monday through Thursday. Sharing the knowledge of the healthcare industry.  Teaching students the importance of accurate medical coding.
cons: Not much training for a new instructor.  Always felt like a bit disconnected to the program.  Never felt appreciated not only for a job well done but when I would step up and take on additional hours.  Working 14 hour days and not even a thank you.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Fun to work at, worked hard, but got rewarded with monthly team builders and lunches. Team atmosphere, very much like a family there. Made friends that last longer than employment.
cons: raises were based off the prior year but only given at a certain time each year. (October). If you started in May, then you had to wait until the following October before an increase.

pros: Generally good immediate faculty members to work with. We care about each other because management doesn't.
cons: Management and higher ups do not care about individual employees. Company was recently acquired by SJVC that does not have a stellar record either. They can't even keep their own programs accredited. Things are either ridiculously micromanaged or no one knows who is in charge. The benefits are a joke.

pros: Everyone is professional, hardworking & fun to work with. All ideas and comments are taken into consideration, and all employees are focused on enhancing the student's experience. Carrington & DeVry do an amazing job at making their employees feel welcome & significant. Even higher management will sit down with you if you need clarity on a situation. Everyone is seen and treated as a significant part of Carrington's team.
cons: The coffee could be better, but you can get up cup from the cafe in the building.

job_title: Student Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Decent salary, great coworkers, sometimes rewarding
cons: NO TRAINING for ANY positions! Your coworkers are the ones expected to train you, but the expectations are just as high as if you did receive comprehensive training. Do not care or consider the needs of employees, are not student-centric (only care about certificate students because it's fast profits), add more work and responsibilities without increasing salary or incentives, do not fill open positions when employees leave so constantly understaffed, move people around different campuses without their approval or consent.

pros: Small campus, very close knit staff. Very motivated students.
cons: Few raises, pay is less then working in the field, insurance is very expensive and doesn't cover anything. The turnover is high, they fire all the wrong people for all the wrong reasons.

pros: Carrington College is a great place to work. They offer very competitive pay and great benefits. Executive Leadership promotes a healthy work/life balance. One of the best benefits is that the company works hard to promote from within, offering a great career path to its employees.
cons: I wouldn't necessarily consider this a con; however, depending what department you work in, change can be a constant. Typically this is for support functions. Overall the company does a great job in creating a strategic plan and sticking to it.

job_title: Social Media Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Supportive colleagues and supervisors who care about doing what's best for our students
Competitive compensation
Generous benefits and time off
Wonderful students
Professional development opportunities
cons: Public perception of the organization doesn't reflect actual company culture, goals, or student sentiment

review_title: The gold standard for technical education!
pros: Great benefits, great colleagues. The home office team is wonderful. The provost is one of the most inspiring people I've ever known.
cons: The company is moving fast in the right direction, making changes, etc. It's sometimes hard to keep up. You have to be motivated to change and work towards improving the college, which isn't hard, but it's sometimes overwhelming.

pros: Family environment where you are appreciated for the work that you do. Worked at other schools where you are afraid of being laid off at any time and here you feel secure. The students are amazing! Management wants your input every step of the way in almost every decision. They invest in you as an employee and the FREE education at DEVRY is amazing!
cons: I have no complaints about Carrington.

pros: Loved my teaching team and the "local" management.  Very supportive
cons: Need to tighten up who gets into the program.  Expect everyone to success especially with the high cost that students pay, but some students just do not have what it takes and should not have ever entered the program.  Definate pressure to  fill seats and push them through at all costs.

pros:
Students try hard
Can work remotely
cons:
Management can't keep good people
Didn't get feedback on teaching for years
Inconsistent teaching schedule

pros: Everyone believes the sun will come out tomorrow.  (Or at least we try to tell ourselves that we believe this.)
cons: It never does.  (It is not only another promise made to us, but ten more that we have to make to the field.)  Right now, it keeps my kids in braces.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Education of students. Members of the education/academic team who really cared and worked hard for students.
cons: Inability to increase the speed of making improvements due to confusion among the leadership and questionable motives.

job_title: Prefer Not to Tell in Phoenix, AZ
pros: benefits are good and most of the staff is experienced and knowledgable
cons: Management.....management....management.  The organization's leadership is constantly in transition and the President of the schools are clueless that everything is not about their failing results.     Leadership 101 if you take care of the people (or act as though you care) everything would be work better.

pros: Colleagues and students are great,
cons: Upper management is in chaos.  The director does not know what she is doing The teachers are not supported and the Program Directors are not getting any communication from the national deans.  It is s mess, The Board will most likely be closing down the nursing programs cuz we do not have enough teachers and teachers are teaching classes without being approved.

pros: All of the colleagues here really  bond - we had our holiday party yesterday and had such a great time - we had probably 100 colleagues with fun games and bowling!  I love it here - lots of raffle prizes - the Director really made us feel special.
cons: Some of the employees came in late and disrupted the party.

pros: Great people, chance to travel, and students.
cons: High pressure may be good for some. Their focus is not on students but on the bottom line, that is if you really care about helping people make a change in their life then this is not the place for you. Management likes cliques.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Decent parking for  some employees
cons: Low pay, no training, materials for instruction scarce, an executive director who bullies and has his 'favorites'. A Dean who learned bullying from the ED, has little experience as a dean and no experience as dean of academics. The dean gossips about others and does so in a demeaning and cruel way. They will ask you to work 10-12 hours a day with the promise of Fridays off, yet you'll take home work for Friday and the weekend.

review_title: Worst professional working environment and leadership of any company I've worked for.....
pros: The students are the only reason anyone stays with Carrington. Without the students. there is absolutely no reason to continue working there.
cons: For the most part, the senior and executive management, especially at the home office and campus level (executive director) are incompetent, inexperienced, and hired for reasons other than business acumen. They are mostly from the previous acquisitions that DeVry made in each regional market. No integrity or knowledge of how to manage a successful team is in evidence. Metrics based and not a complement if you do anything right. The culture is based upon making your boss look good at all expense and covering for their incompetence.  If you try to do something to improve operational efficiencies or processes, you are branded as a trouble-maker and summarily written up on a "performance improvement plan" with jacked up charges, with the outside door the only answer.  Several of my former colleagues have been (unfairly) the target of this treatment and it is a pattern that is repeated throughout the system.  Unhappy employees reside at Carrington, only there because they need the job. Most everyone I know is actively seeking other employment.  Micro-management, bullying, and condescension are the values management seems to utilize in their attempt to continue their fife-dom of personal ego and control.  Old, outdated systems, processes, and outmoded thinking abound. No original ideas or tolerance thereof is permitted.

job_title: Enrollment Services Representative in Spokane Valley, WA
pros: You at least got an office?
cons: You prey on young woman/men who have no income to borrow thousands to complete a certificate that is likely  to pay 12.00 an hour at best. The enrollment services department is like the greasy used car salesman no one wishes they had encountered. The department is very fake!!!

pros: The culture amazing within my department and team synergy dull the pain from working with other areas of the business.
cons: Narrow minded leaderships, too many remote workers with no accountability, senior leaders are MIA and fail to provide proper support.

job_title: Massage Therapy Program Director in Boise, ID
pros: I loved the program and teaching the students.  It was amazing to enlighten their lives and give them a career.
cons: Management, the parent company (DeVry, Inc.) and the behind the scenes was derogatory, negative, and deceptive in the long run.  I could not ethically stay with the company.

pros: Our culture is one that focuses on care. This makes coming into work each day a pleasure. We focus on caring about one another, as well as caring about our students and potential students. Focusing on doing the right thing makes me feel good about what I do each day.
cons: I don't have any at this time.

pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Carrington College California are that you get an opportunity to help students get an education.
cons: Some of the worst reasons to work at Carrington College California are that you are concerned about student opportunities when they graduate.

pros:
Educational environment provides challenges and gratification
My colleagues are top notch in their field
Colleagues are recognized for their achievements and going beyond their scope
Flexibility with my work schedule
Exceptional pay
Exceptional health benefits
cons:
This industry is heavily regulated therefore government is a heavy presence
Your schedule is based around student needs, therefore it can fluctuate

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Salary is good, benefits great, 401K, I like my hours
cons: Going through an "organizational remodel" which has left employees feeling unsupported and insecure.  Not a lot of direction. A lot of time spent on days off working at mandatory meetings or just doing the typical grading/lesson planning

job_title: Student Finance Advisor in Stockton, CA
pros: Colleagues are friendly, and all work well together, My training was real helpful and made me feel confident while taking on this position that I have not had much experience in.  Even though I am fairly new everyone here has made me feel welcomed and appreciated.
cons: No cons at the moment, extremely happy.

review_title: Not a good company to work for
pros:
Great benefits
Nice people to work with 
Company is good about giving you the necessary supplies/equipment to do your job
Pay is competitive with or better than a lot of other schools out there
cons:
Extremely reactive company
Management is unprofessional and unappreciative of faculty 
Home office does not address issues going on at the campus level
Do not promote from within

job_title: Program Director in San Leandro, CA
pros: Good benefit package.  Medical, dental, vision, ortho, matching 401K, excellent vacation and paid time off plan.  You can buy an additional week of vacation for 80% of your wage.  Nice working environment, good people.
cons: Carrington is currently working to make the salaries more competitive, not sure how soon they will be able to accomplish this task.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Citrus Heights, CA
pros: I have been working for Carrington for over 10 years and even though there has been changes. We do have the best interest of our students when helping them achieve their new educational goals.
cons: Every company has areas of opportunity but I focus on the positive and look how my position helps our students achieve their end results.

review_title: Used to be a great company
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Benefits, cross training, and journey with students.
cons: Upper management made it hard to do our job and be successful.

pros: Great atmosphere to work in, love my fellow colleagues because we are always there for each other.  I feel the upper management cares what we are doing on campus and they are there for support.
cons: The only con would be our computer system always going down.

job_title: Pharmacy Technology Instructor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Walk in the door and they really put on a friendly face. Always trying to improve on protocols for student happiness.
cons: The "appreciation" they try to show to students is lost when it comes to the instructors. Most any student complaint is taken as gospel and the instructor is not even allowed to defend by showing what is going on in the classroom.

pros: Wonderful co-workers (at the Program Director level and below) and students; very rewarding helping students excel academically and learn a valued trade; and desirable location.
cons: Very poor senior management at the campus and home office levels, high turnover rate, and FTC lawsuit against parent company (DeVry Education Group) in process.

pros: The college values nursing faculty and appreciates each as individuals and what each has to contribute to the curriculum.
cons: Portland campus closed.  This was a real shame for the city.  Wish they could have done more to keep the campus open.

pros: You feel valued and actually want to go to work everyday. The management is amazing.
cons: There are really no cons for this employer. They pay for your college if you need it.

job_title: Registered Dental Hygienist/Teaching Dental Assisting in Tucson, AZ
pros: Teamwork and communication are some of the best qualities here at Carrington.
cons: My department is small. There is only myself in my department. I have to reach out to other campuses to have specific help. But, it's nice to have that option.

review_title: Medical Assisting instructor for adult education.
job_title: Medical Assisting Instructor in Dallas, TX
pros: A conducive environment. Great team of coworkers. Great learning environment for students with top of the line equipment. Great staff and faculty cohesiveness.
cons: Wrong area for profit. Could have been in a better building. A building that did not have sewer system problems.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Tempe, AZ
pros: None for the students. This is another degree mill scam, which is why I left. All they want is the students money.
cons: Carrington college (their third name already, they've had a few name changes...). No pre reqs required and 50 grand.. It disgusts me that people who fail nursing pre reqs can go pay 50 grand to get their nursing degree from a school like Carrington College that doesn't require anything...

pros: My boss gave me full support and would let me try out my ideas that I wanted to use in class.
cons: Takes along time to get full time status.

pros: Fellow teachers and program directors; helpful support staff
cons: Local management layer chopped off, management is now off campus; onboarding process rough and incomplete; supervisor is unfamiliar with my program

review_title: Management is incompetent and out of touch
pros:
Good benefits
Fair salary
Awesome coworkers who work hard and are really invested in the students
cons: Portland management is hostile, ridiculous and sucks at communicating with employees.

pros: Time off, making a difference in student's lives.
cons: Everything else-politics, back-stabbing, unethical management.  Deserves all the government scrutiny it is currently getting.  It needs to be held under a stronger microscope because this place is not what it claims to be. Lacks integrity.

review_title: It was a roller-coaster. A lot of ups and downs but helped me grow professionally
pros: Great team environment. Recognized for hard effort. Challenging work. Free tuition at Devry University.
cons: Office closed down. No work-life balance. Salary.

pros: The faculty and staff are very professional and friendly.  They truly care about the students' success.
cons: The pay and benefits are below the industry standard.  Especially for part-time.

pros: administrators listened to my input

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Currently there are no pro's, other than excellent health insurance.
cons: Pay is exceedingly low, new management is completely profit oriented.  They have taken all authority away from faculty in the classroom, and students can get away with anything they want, including cheating.  As long as they are generating money for the school, anything is acceptable.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pleasant Hill, CA
pros: I work with a great team.

pros: Good pay, good schedule, good benefits

review_title: Used to be better, change in management created a downside.

pros: Carrington is a Great place to work
